content.description: Slab up low-angle face to access a left-facing dihedral. Follow your instincts up some groovy climbing until you see nothing but the sky. Descend by walkscrambling off the back and scythe around to climber's R and down an obvious, semi-chossy (aren't they all?) gully to return to "Go".
content.protection: Per Mr Keith: "gear to 2". BYOA (bring your own anchor)
content.location: Uhhh.... Right of Center(line)... and L of Hell Hath No Fury.

content.description: Low-angle face climbing without much pro. Take the the path of least resistance up a lichenous face to an anchor consisting of 2 rusted, 516" buttonheads. Descend by walkscrambling off the back and scythe around to climber's R and down an obvious, semi-chossy (aren't they all?) gully to return to "Go".

Slab up to a so-called crack system. Groovy. Continue until you confront a steepening crack. Climb it. Descend by walkscrambling off the back and scythe around to climber's R and down an obvious, semi-chossy (aren't they all?) gully to return to "Go".
content.protection: Limited. Your eyes are the best option for solving the equation.
content.location: See route description and you'll work it out. I believe in you.

content.description: As Mr. Keith says - it's a "lovely line". Climb that. Let your nose be your guide. Descend by walkscrambling off the back and scythe around to climber's R and down an obvious, semi-chossy (aren't they all?) gully to return to "Go".
content.protection: Per TGDCG - "small to 2" including a gear anchor", i.e. BYOA (bring your own anchor).
content.location: There is a groovy line in the approximate middle of the formation.

content.description: North facing slab, I mean really slabby. It is located on the north side of the larger formation just west of the High Rappel formation. Access from behind the pinnacle.
